okay so if you're if you're building a machine learning application there are
some really common challenges that you'll be facing one of those is just the process of moving code from one
physical environment to another the code doesn't just it's not just conceived in production it comes from somewhere it
comes from a staging environment a test environment a dev environment at some point there was a human sitting in front
of a laptop pressing keys and like our friend plows the forklift driver is
aware moving code from one physical environment to another can lead to death and destruction
so what we need is something that gives us portability we want to be able to forklift code from one place to another
and portability is what allows us to package all of our pieces together not
just our application but everything that describes our infrastructure to put it into one nice neat little package and be
able to move it together because there's a fundamental difference between running things on your laptop
and running it in production or anywhere else in the cloud another big problem is
complexity we tend to have this sort of outsized view of the machine learning components within our application but it
doesn't necessarily reflect reality we generally see something closer to this where all of the supporting pieces that
everything surrounding that machine learning model that's really the bulk of the system that we're building and what
we need to support before we can even build models we need to collect our data ingest it explore it analyze it validate
it transform it and then we can split up into tests and training clusters from
there we can turn it into a format that our models understand that we can then use to build models once we've done that
we need to validate them version them audit and distribute them if they're too big
to fit on a single note we want to be able to split them up across resources and when we get new data we want to
update our models make sure that we're training them continuously those models
live somewhere they live inside an application which means a lot of business logic that could be a giant
tree in and of itself there's infrastructure for serving that and for
having a UI so that users can interact with it that application lives somewhere it lives inside a platform and all the
familiar tools like monitoring logging robust the icd processes all of those
are in addition to your machine learning models so to handle that type of
complexity we need something that gives us composability that allows us to create logical groups modular components
that we can then reuse another big problem is maintaining all of those pieces but are we able to identify
errors to resolve them to fix them a recover from them and prevent them from
happening again if we do fix bugs how quickly can we do that and if we introduce new bugs can we
roll back to previous versions of our application we need something that's composable that can automate many of
those processes and shorten that development lifecycle and the last major challenge is capacity planning when you
have a machine learning application you have pieces that have very different resource footprints training is very
resource intensive memory and CPU it hogs all of them and even when you have
established patterns it can be difficult to use your resources efficiently not to mention when you have spikes like data
fluctuations when you get too much or too little more than you're expecting or if you just have a lot of users on your
system and the load is high we need something that gives us scalability that's kubernetes native can leverage
all of the scalability goodness that these thousands of contributors have added to the kubernetes platform and
that allows us to provision in our resources automatically so let's check

the challenges and these are this is what went into the creation of the queue
flow platform the main goal behind it is to make it easy for everyone to develop deploy and manage portable scalable
machine learning everywhere so we care about number one portability and we want to be able to move our application from
one physical environment to another and and not just the ml pieces but the entire stack everything that describes
our infrastructure all those supporting pieces we also care about scalability it's we want a kubernetes native
solution because this reduces the variability between our environments this means that we can move it between
on-prem and different cloud providers and mini cube and it also means that we
can leverage all of the magical networking goodness that communities provides and services can just call each other by name instead of having to worry
about poor conflicts and where things are running physically the third thing we care about composability we want that
single unified tool for running processes that are very common in machine learning we want to be able to
wrap everything up into a nice neat package and tie a bow around it so we
don't want to just support the application that's running in production we want the whole lifecycle from design
and exploration all the way through test staging production environments and then
we also want to support changes to production so going back and building new models and replacing old ones and we
want support for specialized hardware like the GPUs that you're instantiated right now and and TP use TPU stands for
tensor processing unit it it's like a GPU but it's specific to running in Google data centers it's also
a hardware accelerator because if you know what you're doing you can use those to reduce costs and improve your model
performance oki flows entirely open-source it's for anyone who's involved in building a machine learning application we have a
